segments.text: It's a... First, how did you arrive at the name of the scientist and the location of the plant you wanted to go to in Germany?
Well, before we left the United States, we had made up a complete list of the co-hydrogenation plants and the facial trough plants.
People who had...
corresponded with the Germans and had been in Germany and knew the location of plants.
And we had all corresponded with German scientists of one kind or another during our experimental work and our early work.
So we had a pretty good idea of the major people that were going to be involved.
And from them we learned about other people and so on and so on.
We started out with a good itinerary, I think, and then expanded it as we got into the Germans.
Okay.
Well, you seem to know as early as 43 that you're going to pick these plants out.
That seemed awfully early to me to realize where the plants were historically.
Oh, no.
I think we knew the location of most of the German colonization plants, even in the late 30s and early 40s.
We knew all of that.
See, they're very big plants.
And of course, we were greatly involved in this technology in the Vera Mines.
We had been working on it seven or eight years in the Vera Mines.
So we knew most of this material.
And there had been articles published about the plants and things like that and their building and their construction and so on and so forth.
So through the technical literature and through correspondence and through the knowledge of these German scientists, we had a pretty good picture of what we were
going to see and where we were going to see it and who we were going to see it.
Well, I'm amazed, too, that you talk in your article about the way that bombing slowed down the production of synthetic fuels.
It doesn't seem to have done that in other industries.
Why synthetic fuels?
I can't answer that question completely, but
I think it was because they did know the location of the plants, and they were very big plants.
And the Americans took over that daylight bombing, and I think they got over these plants and hit them very, very heavily.
So the time we got over there, a lot of these plants were a wreck, really.
What did the British do exactly?
Were they all alone from the planning from 43 on and going into these plans?
And did they take separate or duplicate records?
The British, when we were organizing our teams here in the United States in late 43, I guess it was, wait a minute, the war ended in 45, didn't it?
Mm-hmm.
In late, in 44 and early 45 when we were organizing our teams in this country, the British were doing the same thing.
They were organizing teams in Great Britain to go into these plants.
And you know the British had one coal hydrogenation plant at Billingham, England that was already operating.
And they had, they had corresponded with IG Farben to a very large extent.
And in fact, I think IG Farber had assisted the British in the design of this plant, probably to some extent in construction.
So the British were very familiar with what was going on in Germany, and they organized their own teams.
Actually, when we got into the field, we were often combined.
It often was a team made up of partly British and partly Americans, or it might have been a complete American team, or it might be a complete British team.
But we work cooperatively throughout.
And a lot of the reports are written by partly British and partly American.
Well, did they select a different sort of records to take back to Britain, I wonder?
No, I think we all had pretty much the same records.
And I think they had copies of all of our reports, and we had copies of all of their reports.
How did you decide which material to eliminate when you wrote your reports?
you speak of eliminating some material.
I don't remember that we eliminated much of anything.
We tried to cover in our own reports practically every phase of technology which had any new aspects to it.
In addition to that, we often brought back German documents as supplementary to what we had written and so on and so on.
But I really don't remember that there was any process of elimination except that we might decide that
The material that we saw in the file or something like that was routine records, business records, and things like that.
And we dropped those because they had no technologic interest to us at all.
Those we didn't care about.
We didn't care whether the Germans sold 10,000 tons a day or whether they sold 1,000 tons a day or who paid for it.

Yeah, I should have jotted the page down, but you say you're talking about in 1945, you're talking about difficulties you're going to have in assuming this material, absorbing this material and releasing it later on, and you talk about the volume material and you say, well, some was...
was automatically eliminated.
Well, I think it was.
But I think it was largely routine material that we felt added nothing to our understanding of the plants or the technology.
OK.
Along that line, and it says you talk about all microfilming is really what you're talking about.
And Odell, is that how you pronounce his name?
Odell.
Odell, OK.
and Odell is discussing a process, and you say, well, I suppose all this is getting microfilmed, or we're getting copies of the microfilm, and you say just certain copies of the microfilm.
In the cases of Mr. Odell's report, we know that he has written it from notes taken immediately on the field and placed very little reliance upon the microfilms.
And I really couldn't understand exactly, it's talking about carbon dioxide content in a,
and slagging units is in the capacity.
I really couldn't understand exactly what that had to do with report writing.
Is that were most of the reports written from the field notes or most of them from the microfilm documents?
Most of them were written from the field notes.
From the field notes.
Yeah.
And then did you go back later on and check the microfilm documents?
That, I guess, was up to the individual authors.
In some cases, I think they probably did.
In some cases, they probably didn't.
Well, it seems to me there's a tremendous, the best I can tell from everything, there's a tremendous amount of microfilm documents.
And I'm having a very hard time sorting through and seeing what the follow-up was.
I can't at all feel certain that the microfilms were extensively relied upon in writing these reports.
I think it was mostly field notes.
How were the original 23 investigators chosen who went to Germany?
We had meetings here in Washington between the oil people and mainly the Bureau of Mines and some of the people in the Department of Interior.
And all of those meetings, there were four or five of those meetings,
Out of those meetings, the oil people suggested certain people that they wanted, thought to be qualified for the mission.
Bear in mind, they suggested a number of people, and out of that came the first 23 people.
Yeah, there seems an argument evolves, best I can tell.
The argument seems to evolve here.
Some people agree to go and then back up, and some people join later on.
I think that's right.
Was there some sort of a complication?
I don't think there was any complication.
I think oftentimes it was a question of the man's, well, first, how badly he was needed here in the United States.
Could he give up the time to go on a month or two expedition into Germany?
And then it was a few questions of people's age and health that were involved.
Did you attend the 1941 meeting with Hickeys when it calls together 1,000 of the most prominent men in the oil industry?
No.
All right.
Obviously, your scrapbook has demonstrated you began earlier than I thought you did, so I'm not sure that question is relevant anymore.
But I was wondering, as early as 1941 then, he's already calling forth 1,000 people from the oil industry to talk about synthetic fuels?
Yeah, I expect so.
Who was C.S.
Snodgrass?
Snodgrass was in the Trojan War.
Petroleum Administration for War, is that right?
Yeah.
Snodgrass was, I don't remember his exact position, but he was in the Petroleum Administration for War and took a very active part in organizing these teams and so on and so forth.
And he knew the Petroleum Industry well, and he knew the Department of Interior fairly well.
Actually, Snodgrass was a very good friend of mine.
Well, I don't know whether he's still in it or not.
I was going to ask you if you knew Snodgrass now.
You've already answered that question.
Is he the one who brings you actively into this synthetic oil search?
No, no, I think I wouldn't say that, but he brought a lot of the oil people into the search.
Describe him.
What was he like?
What's his background?
I can't find anything out about him.
He's
His background was, he had been, I can't give you too much of his background to tell you the truth.
He had been in the oil industry for quite a while and he knew quite a lot of the technology of the oil and gas industry and had quite a bit of administrative experience.
And then I don't know exactly how he got into the Petroleum Administration for War, but I'm sure it's through one of the outcome is that he appears in the Petroleum Administration for War.
Why was the military not included in this search from the beginning?
Now, the Navy evidently is very interested.
Why not the Army?
The Navy decided to organize their own group of people to go over there and investigate synthetic films.
And Pettyjohn, the man you're going to see, he was head of the Institute of Gas Technology.
Pettyjohn was a commander, I believe, in the Navy, and was very active in the Navy.
And he got into this fairly early, and he thought that a military team, particularly a Navy team, could do a better job than a civilian team.
And in a way, the two teams

competed they covered somewhat the same targets we covered and i don't know what happened to their documents did they write reports too yes i'm sure they did okay and uh now what what i need to do now is to go over these charts which i have labeled one two and three and they're obviously your charts because there were some things about going over the charts i couldn't understand from a
You know exactly how advice and so forth put in.
Chart one is called the Organizational Structure for the Oil Mission in 1944 and 1945.
Now here you see, this is where the Fuels and Lubricants Subcommittee, where Snodgaris is chairman.
A Technical Industrial Intelligence Committee.
Now were these people from the oil industry itself, or was this you?
No, I think that was mainly from the oil industry.
But it might also have included some government people, but I was not on it.
I was not on it.
And then here's CIOs, you know, the Combined Intelligence Objectives Committee.
All right, now, so is the technical oil mission feeding information both to the TIIC and to the CIOS?
I suspect so.
OK.
So information flows both ways.
Both ways.
Both ways.
Now, and then the TIIC, what relationship does it have to the Fuels and Lubricants Subcommittee?
Is this a directive?
I think this is part of the technical.
Oh, OK. Yeah.
All right, I see.
And I didn't even remember that Snodgrass was chairman of that, but I think I do now that you note it here.
All right, and so.
Comforth, I had forgotten completely.
He, however.
I remember this faintly now.
Petty John and his group in the Navy went over there as a Navy group, and I think they had their path more or less laid out as a Navy group, and didn't have much trouble getting over there.
We, on the other hand, were all civilians.
and we had no business in the war zone.
So we had to be taken in in the Army on some status or another, and we had to have uniforms and so on and so forth, so we weren't arrested for spies over there, some darn thing like that.
And Comforth, it seems to me that he arranged most of this stuff with the,
through the Army so that we could be processed through the Army and could fly over there and could fly into the combat zones and so on and so forth.
All right.
You're forcing me to rely heavily on 30 years ago.
Oh, I know it's hard to do.
All right.
It says Combined Intelligence Objective Subcommittee, all right, which is, you know, again, CIOS.
This is from Britain.
The Bureau of Mines, all right?
Yeah, right.
All right.
Now then, and out of here come the translated reports.
But the Combined Intelligence Objective Subcommittee included not only people from the Bureau of Mines, but also the people from the oil industry.
All right, so the oil industry was involved in,
in the Combined Intelligence Subcommittee here.
And then it was from this work to the Translated Reports King.
Now, it says 306 rolls of microfilm, which were German.
And they go to the Library of Congress.
And from the Library of Congress, they're to go out to industry.
Now, are these the reels of microfilm from which a series of five indexes were published?
I never saw those microfilms.
I knew we were making microfilms, but I never saw them.
Okay.
And then the translated reports go on into the American Petroleum Institute technical oil mission.
Yeah, right.
Now, what does the film study groups do?
I couldn't understand how they fit into dissemination of information.
I don't know that either.

See, when I came back here, and probably a lot of that film studying was done back here in the United States, I wasn't involved in that because I went back to my old task of running synthetic fuels for the Bureau of Mines.
Oh, okay.

So while I knew a lot about this, I knew this was all going on, and I knew the reports were all being edited and that they had a technical group, which included some of the Bureau of Mines people, but was mainly petroleum people.
and that they were trying to get out final reports on this thing.
And that's the way it was done.
Let's see if we've got any.
Have you got any of the old reports?
Yeah, yeah.
I've got some.
You know how they're put together and so on and so forth.
Well, let me see if I've got some here.
One thing here on tape.
Come on now.
There we go.
Now, I realize there was a close contact between Standard Oil and Farben.
I didn't realize there was a contact between the British and the German synthetic oil production.
I wonder when that develops.
Well, that must have started, the British started their work on coal hydrogenation, if my memory serves me well, about the early 1930s, 31 or 32.
And that was all started at Billingham, England, just in the northeastern part of England.
And then later on, the British built a coal-hydrogenation plant.
And I think this was essentially after the Burgess design and followed closely the types of plants that were being built in Germany at that point.
And they ran that plant for several years prior to the war.
I think they were working on coal-hydrogenation then.
But then during the war, I think they went over to tar-hydrogenation because they could get more products out there.
And they used that plant to make aviation gasoline during the war.
And I'm sure people like Kenneth Gordon and so on and so forth, and Holroyd, who were with ICI, were well acquainted with the people in Germany who were doing the work on co-hydrogenation.
And don't forget, Dr. Calvert, what's your first name?
Bob.
Bob, I knew that.
And don't forget that...
that this whole German technology had been evolving over a period of 20 years.
And of course, the people who were interested in coal work were well aware of what the Germans were doing all this 20 year period of time.
And then when it finally evolved, I think they put up their first plant in about 1925.
So there was great technical interest in that plant.
And the British, I think the British thought that
Great Britain has never had any substantial supply of oil until they brought in the North Sea oil.
And I think the British thought that they would eventually be producing oil from coal in England.
The situation has turned out to be quite different really, but that's what they thought at that time.
So that was why they built that first coal hydrogenation plant.
So the translated reports go to the American Petroleum Institute of Technical Oil and Mission Study Group.
And this says Publication Board of Department of Commerce to Industry.
This group, I think you told me, and as I remember, was headed by Al Miller from Sinclair Oil Company at that time.
They've since gone into another.
Who's Sinclair going to?
I don't know.
I never can remember.
I can never remember the combination either.
But that group functioned for a couple of years.
And then it was going to break up.
And at that time, the Department of Commerce decided that they would become the depository for these reports.
And I think they also distributed a lot of these reports for people who wanted them later on.
And later on, it broke up.
And then I don't know what happened to the rest of it.
to the story.
OK. And then so I see then, so the reports translated here, went here, and then on to industry as industry called for them.
Yeah, right, right.
Now, I had a terrible time with this one.
Our Petroleum Administration for the War, Secretary of Interior, Ickes.
I can understand that.
Now, the Petroleum Industry War Council
I wonder what in the world it did with William R. Boyd as chairman.
I didn't remember.
I guess Boyd was chairman.
I didn't know that.
I was never in on any meetings of the Petroleum Industry War Council.
But they advised the Department of Interior, and I think the government generally,

As to the oil situation and supplying the allies with oil and moving oil around this country and meeting the submarine threat and transporting oil from your state of Texas up to the east, you remember the submarines were sinking ships at a hell of a rate there.
And I think this group was trying to coordinate the petroleum industry with the war effort, largely done through ICAS.
Okay.
All right.
And then we have technical committees and technical advisories.
R.E.
Wilson at that time, he was president of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, as I remember it.
And I really don't know what his function was, because these were committees that I was not involved with.
Okay, but what about the special advisory group down here in 1945?
I wasn't involved.
You weren't involved in that?
No.
OK.
I have you somehow connected with the Special Advisory Bureau.
I don't know why I put it.
What I was trying to, interesting in finding it.
I think the thing you've got to distinguish here is that a lot of this is connected with the oil industry.
And in general,
I had little or no contact with the oil industry, other than meetings and so on and so forth, occasional meetings.
See, we were pretty much involved in synthetic fuels, not oil problems.
Now, I only have one other question from this technical oil mission meeting that I couldn't understand.
And between 45 and 47, there's a sizable amount of work to be done, as you point out, in December of 45 until 47 when these reports begin to come out.
I assume that in that period when these mission documents were team written for all practical purposes, that they must have then is when they must have
gone through flow records and...
Yes, I did.
Okay.

Then it's when you went back and looked over... We went through the flow records and we went through laboratory records and we went through technology, small scale and large scale, and it was all written up in these reports.
And then the reports come out in 47.
Did you ever feel called upon to go back and check these reports?
No, I never did go back and check.
But now other people may have.
Al Miller and his group, he had a group of people working with him, and they may have done a lot of rechecking on this stuff, but I didn't know about that.
All right.
Now, you say you picked eight specialization groups of three to 11 persons, in effect, go into these plants to look them over.
I didn't know there were eight groups, but you may be right.
Well, that's what I say here in this paper.
I don't know whether it's right or not.
Probably reasonably right.
All right.
If that's true, then what kind of aid specialization groups would you pick?
What sort of specialization groups are they talking about?
Would this be engineers, chemical engineers, plant managers?
Is that the kind of team you tried to put together?
What I'm trying to find out is what sort of team did you put together and did you pick on?
Well, it was a very chaotic, and I would say,

not particularly precise arrangement, we would generally try to get maybe one good chemical man and one plant man and perhaps one man who had had a lot of process experience to go to a given plant to look the thing over
and begin the preliminary report on it.
And we would expect that team of maybe three or four or five people to at least write one report.

Now, that report was then discussed at meeting of the team members, and probably from that we might decide whether we should go back there and investigate certain phases of it that weren't covered in the first report and so on and so forth.
Teams were scattered all over Europe.
Our meetings were never on any definite scheduled basis.
When the reports were out, I'm sure that not all the team members in Germany had a chance to read it.
And so it was a very loose sort of an arrangement, you know.
And it might often involve just who was available in Brussels or London to go on a specific mission.
I thought that was probably what it was.
I also suspect that a lot of the team members did not see reports that other team members had written until we were back here in the United States.
Was the fuel and lubricant subcommittee controversial?
No, I don't believe so.
I don't believe there was any question of controversy.
Well, there's...
Unless there's some things I missed.
You see, part of the time I was in the field doing investigations of the plants and so on and so forth.
And at times like that, I was not very well aware of what was happening in London where the central organization was trying to function and to send the teams out and so on and so forth.
Who was Dr. T.G.
Delbridge?
Delbridge was a man from the Atlantic Refining Company.
And I don't think he went on the missions, did he?
No.
He evidently is...
But I think Delbridge was a very knowledgeable man.
He was a very good technical man.
And I think Delbridge suggested to us a lot of members from the petroleum industry that might be useful on these missions.
He writes a report in August of 1944 for the Technical Industrial Intelligence Committee
that seems to give some direction to what you're looking for in Germany.
I wouldn't be surprised.
He was a considerably older man than I was at that time, and he knew the industry well, and he knew the technology well, and I'm sure that he might well have written reports about it.
